title: 107_s2570
content: SECTION 1. TEMPORARY INCREASE OF MEDICAID FMAP. Permitting Maintenance of Fiscal Year 2001 and 2002 FMAP for subsequent years, if lower than previous years, for Medicaid funding. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, there will be a 1 percentage point increase in the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP) for Medicaid funding. Additionally, there will be an increase in the cap on Medicaid payments to territories during this period. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the FMAP for Medicaid funding will increase by 1 percentage point. The cap on Medicaid payments to territories will also increase during this period. Northern Mariana Islands and American Samoa will each receive a 2 percent increase in funding under the Social Security Act. The FMAP increases apply only to title XIX of the Social Security Act and do not apply to certain payments under titles IV and XXI. States are eligible for FMAP increases or cap amount increases based on their State plan under title XIX. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, the FMAP for Medicaid funding will increase by 1 percentage point, and the cap on Medicaid payments to territories will also increase. The eligibility under title XIX of the Social Security Act must not be more restrictive than the eligibility in effect on January 1, 2002. This does not affect a State's flexibility with benefits offered under the State Medicaid program. Definitions include FMAP as the Federal medical assistance percentage and State as defined in the Social Security Act. The term "State" is defined as per title XIX of the Social Security Act. Effective October 1, 2003, this section will be repealed. SEC. 2008 of Title XX of the Social Security Act provides $4,430,280,000 in additional temporary grants for State fiscal relief, available for obligation by States until June 30, 2004, and for expenditure until September 30, 2004. The funds are allotted among States by the Secretary as per a specified table. The table shows the allotment of funds to different states under SEC. 2008 of Title XX of the Social Security Act. Key details include the amount allocated to each state ranging from $126,000 for American Samoa to $459,264,000 for California. The table displays the funds allocated to various states under SEC. 2008 of Title XX of the Social Security Act, with amounts ranging from $11,590,000 for Montana to $156,504,000 for Illinois. The table shows the allocation of funds to different states under SEC. 2008 of Title XX of the Social Security Act, with amounts ranging from $8,382,000 for North Dakota to $693,453,000 for New York. Total allocation of funds to states under SEC. 2008 of Title XX of the Social Security Act is $4,430,280,000. Funds appropriated under this section may be used by a State for services directed at the goals set forth in section 2001. The Secretary shall make a lump sum payment to a State of the total amount of the allotment specified in subsection (b). The term 'State' refers to the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and territories listed in subsection (b). Section 2008 of the Social Security Act, added by this section, is repealed as of January 1, 2005.
